mods:name.mods:affiliation: Department of Botany, University of Wisconsin-Madison, 430 Lincoln Drive Madison, Wisconsin 53706, USA

subSubSection.paragraph: Conostegia D. Don, Mem. Wern. Soc. 4: 316. 1823. Lectotype: Conostegia procera (Sw.) D. Don ex DC. (= Melastoma procera Sw.), designated here.
Synodon Raf., Sylva Tellur. 95. 1838. Lectotype:- Conostegia montana (Sw.) D. Don ex DC.(= Melastoma montana Sw.), designated here.

Species concepts in this revision for the most part follow the morphological species concept as defined by Cronquist (1978) in which species are "the smallest groups that are consistently and persistently distinct, and distinguishable by ordinary means." It is a problematic concept partly because defining "distinct" is subjective and varies across organisms. Nonetheless, it is the most common species concept applied to plants (McDade 1995), and an effort was made to recognize only species that appear distinct. This author views species as hypotheses that are subject to testing. Thus the reader should be aware that some species may someday prove to be synonymous with others, and some species complexes might prove to be made of cryptic species in need of recognition. Properties of other species concepts are desirable, such as defining species based on monophyly (e.g. the phylogenetic species concept), but the lack of enough representative specimens in the phylogenetic analyses of many species, as well as appropriate molecular markers to ascertain clades (species) with confidence, and inherent biological processes such as incomplete lineage sorting, preclude much of its use in the present treatment. In this monograph when a negative measurement is given for the distance between the anther and the stigma, this means that the anthers are below the stigma for that length.

Key to the sections and species of
Conostegia

tr.td:
Sepals not fused into a calyptra, sometimes rupturing late at anthesis into irregular lobes, calyx teeth present at the level of the torus or slightly above; flowers diplostemonous (sect.
Geniculatae
, pro majore parte)
Leaves discolorous, the abaxial surface white to rusty and concealing the surface
Sepals fused and rupturing at anthesis into irregular lobes
Sepals the same texture as the hypanthium, persisting through flowering; anther apex rounded
Sepals hyaline and almost not visible during flowering; anther apex acute
Sepals not evidently fused at anthesis and rupturing into irregular lobes
Calyx teeth adnate to the calyx lobes, barely discernable and not projecting beyond them; petals papillose
Calyx teeth oblong or linear, usually evident and exceeding the calyx lobes; petals glabrous
Abaxial indument rusty colored; calyx teeth usually longer than 2 mm and hooked
Abaxial indument white; calyx teeth up to 1.5 mm long and not hooked
Leaves not discolorous, the abaxial surface visible
Inflorescence axillary or appearing so
Leaves peltate; indument on abaxial leaf surface and hypanthia stellate; flowers 4-merous
Leaves not peltate; indument on abaxial leaf surface and hypanthia glabrous or stellulate lepidote; flowers 4-5 merous
Leaves and hypanthium glabrous or appearing so
Leaf base decurrent on the petiole and lacking domatia at the base abaxially; inflorescence of pedunculate glomerules with sessile flowers and ovate bracteoles
Leaf base acute and usually with domatia at the base abaxially; inflorescence a laxly branched dichasium with pedicellate flowers and linear to lanceolate bracteoles
Leaves with four domatia located abaxially at the base of the leaf
Leaves lacking, or usually with two domatia located abaxially at the base of the leaf

Leaves and hypanthium densely pubescent with long simple or dendritic hairs (some populations of
Conostegia allenii
with glabrous leaves)
Petals acuminate at the apex
Petals rounded at the apex
Leaves with domatia at the base abaxially
Leaves lacking domatia at the base abaxially
Leaves sessile or subsessile
Leaves distinctly petiolate
Inflorescence terminal
Leaves peltate
Leaves petiolate from the lamina base or sessile, not peltate

Hypanthium densely covered with simple hairs sometimes intermixed with stellate hairs; the leaves with simple hairs on both surfaces or just on the abaxial surface; calyx teeth linear to subulate and 2-4 mm long

Hypanthium glabrous to densely covered with stellate and or dendritic hairs; the leaves adaxially glabrous and abaxially glabrescent to densely covered with stellate or dendritic trichomes mostly on the veins; calyx teeth tuberculate to triangular or, if linear, usually less, but up to, 2 mm long
Inflorescences with sessile flowers in bracteate clusters
Leaves sessile and the base decurrent
Leaves petiolate, the base obtuse to acute or rounded
Calyx lobes not evidently fused at anthesis and rupturing, ovate to orbicular and mucronate, the same consistency as the hypanthium
Calyx lobes fused at anthesis, hyaline, and rupturing into irregular lobes
Inflorescences with pedicellate flowers not in clusters
Calyx fused in bud and rupturing into irregular hyaline lobes
Flower 4 merous
Flower 5 merous
Leaves subsessile with rounded to cordate bases; plants overall appearing glabrous but bearing minute inconspicuous trichomes almost invisible to the naked eye; stamens alternately two sizes
Petals linear oblong; Costa Rican endemics
Leaves 5 plinerved; indument of stem apices of asperous headed hairs only; inflorescence branched at the base
Leaves 7 plinerved; indument of stem apices lanate at least in part; inflorescence branched above the base
Petals ovate; Panamanian endemics
Flower regularly arranged at the end of the inflorescence branches and with pink papillose petals
Flowers usually clustered at the end of the inflorescence branches and with white glabrous petals
Calyx not fused in bud and the lobes not rupturing into irregular hyaline lobes, the lobes mostly low and undulate
Flowers large, the petals 9 mm long or more; stigma capitate; ovary totally inferior
Flowers small, the petals usually no more than 5 mm long; stigma truncate to punctiform; ovary at least partly superior
Leaves 5-7 nerved with a broadly rounded to cordate base
Leaves 5-7 plinerved with rounded to mostly acute to attenuate base
Petals magenta
Petals white
Petals ovate; anthers with broad pores
Petals linear-oblong; anthers with small pores
Leaves 3 plinerved, the leaf blade 1.7-9.5 x 0.4-1.7 cm
Leaves 5 plinerved, the leaf blade 4.2-28.4 x 1.4-9.2 cm
Sepals fused into a calyptra, calyx teeth absent, or if present, restricted to the apex of the calyptra; flowers usually pleiostemonous

Calyptra often rupturing at one side or breaking into pieces; style exserted (section
Australis
and
Conostegia cinnamomea
)
Leaf bases with pouch like formicaria; indument of the stems with long simple hairs
Leaf bases without pouch like formicaria; indument of stems absent or of stellate, dendritic or asperous hairs
Stem apices and leaf abaxial surface glabrous or nearly so
Flowers in glomerules at the end of inflorescence branches and subtended by evident bracts and bracteoles; stamens usually less, but up to 15
Flowers regularly arranged at the end of inflorescence branches and without evident bracts; stamens 16 or more in number
Inflorescence a reflexed and pseudoaxillary panicle; flowers (4-) 5-merous
Inflorescence a terminal panicle; flowers usually 6-merous
Leaves with an entire margin and caudate apex
Leaves with a serrulate to serrate margin and acuminate apex
Leaves linear to linear elliptic, up to 3.5 cm wide, attenuate at the base; stamens 16-21
Leaves ovate, 2-7.3 cm wide, obtuse to rounded at the base; stamens 26-36
Stem apices and leaf abaxial surfaces evidently pubescent at least on the veins
Leaf base strongly decurrent on the petiole; leaves sessile or nearly so
Leaf base acute to rounded; leaves petiolate
Leaves linear to linear elliptic, up to 3.5 cm wide
Leaves elliptic to ovate, more than 5 cm wide
Petioles setose adaxially; flower buds covered by foliaceous bracteoles
Petioles glabrescent or variously pubescent, but not setose adaxially; flower buds not covered by foliaceous bracteoles
Floral buds up to 4(-5.5) mm long; petals up to 5 mm long; style lacking a collar around the base
Floral buds more than (4.7-)5.5 mm long; petals 7 mm long or more; base of the style enveloped by a collar
Indument on stems evidently stipitate stellate, not rusty colored; stamens more than 30
Indument on stems sometimes stipitate stellate but not evidently so, rusty colored; stamens up to 24
Flower buds (7.5-) 10-18 mm long, the apex long apiculate
Flower buds 4.7-11 mm long, the apex rounded to short apiculate
Flower buds with the surface sparsely pubescent resulting in a visible surface, constricted below the torus; petioles 1-5 cm long
Flower buds with the surface densely pubescent resulting in a hidden surface, not to slightly constricted below the torus; petioles 0.4-2.5 cm long

Calyptra circumscissle and falling as a unit; style shorter or of equal length than the stamens (section
Conostegia
& section
Geniculatae
, pro minore parte)
Stigma lobed and/or with an evident hole in the middle
Flower buds pyriform to ellipsoid, with an attenuate to apiculate apex, longer than wide
Stem apices and leaf abaxial surface slightly pubescent to evidently pubescent; plants from Mexico
Stems and leaf abaxial surfaces furfuraceous
Stems and leaf abaxial surfaces densely beset with stellate and stalked stellate trichomes

Stem apices and leaves glabrous or with scattered stellate trichomes in
Conostegia chiriquensis
; plants from Costa Rica and Panama
Flower buds 5-7 mm long; petals to 5 mm long, white with a red band at the base; anthers to 2.3 mm long
Flower buds 7-14 mm long; petals at least 8 mm long, white to less commonly lavender; anthers at least 2.5 mm long
Stigma peltate and with a hole in the middle
Stigma barely expanded and lacking a hole in the middle
Flower buds mostly ovoid to spherical with a rounded, mucronate, or broadly acute apex, as long as wide or slightly longer than wide
Stigma capitate, but lacking a large hole in the middle; stigma lobes not conspicuous
Stigma with large hole in the middle; stigma lobes conspicuous
Leaves with two tubercles at the apex of the petiole abaxially; petals pink
Leaves lacking tubercles at the apex of the petiole abaxially; petals white
Floral buds obovoid, constricted near the torus, acute at the apex, the surface smooth; leaves narrowly elliptic
Floral buds spherical, not constricted near the torus, abruptly mucronate apically, the surface inconspicuously to usually evidently tuberculate; leaves elliptic to usually ovate
Bracteoles replaced by persistent clusters of setae; pedicels up to 3 mm long
Bracteoles not consisting of setae, usually early deciduous; pedicels usually more than 3 mm
Style straight; petals apically retuse; leaves stellate pubsecent abaxially
Style curved; petal apex rounded, truncate to emarginate; leaves stellate sometimes stellate pubescent abaxially when young, usually glabrous with age
Leaf margin entire to denticulate; floral buds usually conspicuously tuberculate; Nicaragua to Panama
Leaf margin undulate dentate; floral buds inconspicuously tuberculate; Guatemala and Mexico
Stigma not lobed or with a hole in the middle
Leaf bases with pouch like formicaria; indument of the stems with long simple hairs
Leaf bases lacking formicaria; indument of the stems various but not of long simple hairs
Flowers subtended by persistent foliaceous bracts
Stems and leaves glabrous or with inconspicuous trichomes
Stems and leaves densely pubescent with simple and somewhat branched trichomes
Flowers not subtended by persistent foliaceous bracts
Leaves with the abaxial surface covered with white to tan trichomes, making the actual surface hidden or almost so

Abaxial leaf surface and hypanthium covered with lepidote trichomes; tree reaching about 25 meters tall; calyptra translucent, less pubescent than the hypanthium; seeds about 1.5 mm long; Endemic to the Osa Peninsula, Costa Rica

Abaxial leaf surface and hypanthium covered with stellate trichomes; tree reaching about 15 meters tall; calyptra tan to whitish colored, not translucent, and as pubsecent as the hypanthium; seeds to about 1 mm long
Calyptra with linear appendages at the apex about 2.5 mm long
Calyptra lacking linear appendages at the apex, at most minute bumps present on the apex
Leaves with the abaxial surface glabrous or pubescent, if pubescent, never with the surface hidden
Stem apices and leaf abaxial surfaces pubescent
Leaf adaxial surface and floral buds densely hirsute; inflorescence and bud pubescence purple
Leaf adaxial surface glabrous and floral buds glabrous or beset with stellate or dendritic trichomes; inflorescence and bud pubescence rusty or whitish

Leaves 5-9 plinerved; flowers with small appendages on the calyptra apex; floral buds wider above the torus; petals apically slightly mucronate to acute, especially when seen at anthesis; filaments with an evident geniculation; seeds about 1 mm long

Leaves 3-5 nerved or plinerved; flowers without small appendages on the calyptra apex; floral buds usually not wider above the torus; petals rounded, emarginate or truncate; filaments without an evident geniculation; seeds about 0.5 mm long
Floral buds, veins on leaf abaxial surface and stem apices rusty with small brown dendritic hairs; petals 7 or more mm long; ovary apex elevated into a conspicuous collar around the style base
Stem apices, leaf abaxial surfaces and floral buds densely covered with sessile stellate and/or stipitate stellate trichomes
Leaf and bud indument combining sessile stellate and stipitate stellate trichomes; floral buds with the lobes slightly differentiated at the apex; plants from Cuba and the Dominican Republic
Leaf and bud indument of stipitate stellate trichomes; floral buds with the lobes not differentiated at the apex; plants from Central America
Trees reaching 12 m high; Belize, Guatemala and Honduras
Shrubs rarely reaching 4 m high; Costa Rica

Stem apices and leaf abaxial surfaces sparsely to densely covered with stellate trichomes or sparsely beset with stipitate stellate trichomes, floral buds glabrous or sparsely beset with sessile or less commonly some stipitate stellate trichomes
Leaves 7.1-36 x 2.3-16 cm; inflorescence 7-27.5 cm long, with flowers disposed in umbels terminating the inflorescence branches
Leaves 3.8-21.5 x 1.2-10.5 cm; inflorescence 2.7-18.1 cm, long with flowers not disposed in umbels terminating the inflorescence branches
Stem apices and abaxial leaf surfaces with sessile and stipitate stellate trichomes
Stem apices and abaxial leaf surfaces with sessile stellate trichomes
Leaves densely stellate pubescent on abaxial leaf surface; lowlands of the Caribbean slope of Nicaragua, Costa Rica and Panama
Leaves with trichomes mostly restricted to the veins; widely distributed
Stem apices and leaf abaxial surfaces glabrous or with very inconspicuous trichomes
Inflorescence pendant; flowers with purple petals; seeds muriculate
Inflorescence erect; flowers with white or pink petals; seeds smooth
Flowers sessile or on pedicels up to about 1 mm long
Flowers on pedicels 1.5 mm long or usually longer than 2 mm

Flowers clustered at the end of the inflorescence branches; flower buds up to and usually less than 11 mm long; Southern Mexico (Oaxaca and Veracruz) through Central, and South America, only
Conostegia superba
reaching the Caribbean including Jamaica
Petals 7-12 mm; anthers 4-4.5 mm long; stigma capitate; bracteoles up to 6 mm long; flowers 6-8 merous
Petals to 6 mm, less commonly to up to 8.3 mm; anthers to 3.25 mm long; stigma cylindrical to slightly expanded; bracteoles absent or to about 1 mm long; flowers (4-)5-7 merous
Flower buds acute to slightly apiculate at the apex, not contricted in the middle, usually white; inflorescence rachis usually white
Flower buds apiculate at the apex, constricted in the middle, usually pink; inflorescence rachis pink
Flowers not clustered at the end of the inflorescence branches; flower buds 10 mm long or usually longer; Southwest Mexico (Guerrero and Jalisco) or Jamaica
Leaf margin serrulate and cilate; pedicels 2-5 mm long; plants from Southwest Mexico (Guerrero and Jalisco)
Leaf margin not serrulate and cilate; pedicels 5-13 mm long; plants from Jamaica
Hypanthium ribbed, at least towards the base; abaxial leaf surfaces with tuft domatia at the base
Hypanthium not ribbed at the base; abaxial leaf surface lacking tuft domatia at the base
Petals pink
Petals white
